reviewText: For a little while, I felt as if I were watching the old Met.  No giant clock overpowering the set.  No rehearsal room setting.  No Abraham Lincoln, John Lennon, and Queen Elizabeth watching from a gallery.  No aerial acrobatics.  No focus on stage machinery or puppets.  And only a minor re-dating of the story.Then, came a sword altercation filling the stage and overshadowing the Anvil Chorus, hookers visiting Di Luna's camp as the men were preparing to attack the fortress, and Leonora trying to climb the fence to see Manrico in prison.  As Opera New reviewed, "David McVicar is known for filling the stage with extra characters, images, and incidents."  Please, let us keep our attention on the opera, not distracted by irrelevant whatevers.Musically, there is little to fault, nor little to praise excessively.  Dolora Zajick is her usually strong self as Azucena.  Marcello Alvarez is his usual shouting tenor.  Sondra Radvanovsky and Dmitri are their usual non-acting selves.  Stefan Kocan sings quite well, but his facial contortions draw attention away from the voice.  Maria Zifchak (an underappreciated character actress) is particularly strong in the minor tole of Inez.The Met would do well to heed Justin Davidson's advice in New York magazine: "The Met needs [Peter] Gelb's marketing savvy, but Gelb also needs a full partner, an artistic director as powerful and engaged as he is."
summary: Somewhat better than what the Met has been doing

reviewText: ....."Absolutely dreadful!" What a dark, drab production. The sets are terrible. Every scene looks like it is taking place in a concrete bunker. The costumes are hideous. Leonora looks like she is wearing a great coat over her nightgown. Most of the singing and acting is below par. Alvarez is a lyric tenor who doesn't have enough voice to sing the role properly. And his acting is nonexistant. Radvanovsky sings very well, but her acting is uniformly atrocious. Hvorostovsky is pushing his voice too much and his acting consists of frowning and looking handsome. The only decent performance is by Dolora Zajick, who sings brilliantly and acts wonderfully. The direction of this production is appalling. A silly swordfight in the gypsy camp and a completely unnecessary and tasteless scene involving whores in a military camp completely go against what Verdi intended for this opera. Recently the Met has gone Regie with it's horrible La Traviata, it's awful Tosca, it's terrible Carmen, and it's ridiculous La Sonnambula. This production of Il Trovatore is just plain bad. I would recommend instead the Domingo/von Karajan or the Pavarotti/Levine dvds. They are both very good productions and are universes above this mess.

reviewText: Here is a nearly perfect production of a very difficult opera. Get it while you can. It's a treasure.The opera itself has a very convoluted plot. It can be difficult to follow the motivations of the characters, This staging is very quick paced which helps build continuity between the scenes. The set is a little bit strange---very dark. I wondered if it was meant to be a church or a torture chamber at times. The Count's headquarters are like an emergency exit from a factory. None of these minor criticisms detract enough from the performance to matter.The performances of all the singers are superb. Some of the arias are simply spell-binding. Verdi is about the music and this is a singers production. The orchestra does the job and is never in the way. This is one of the best operas on DVD for pure singing that I have seen. Every part is excellent and will have you holding your breath on some of the most beautiful long notes, diminutive expressions and leaps into high territory.When I ordered, I made an error and added this to my cart twice. It was a large order and the DVD was pretty inexpensive so I didn't notice. Now I'm glad to have a spare to loan to friends. It's that good.

reviewText: My relationship with Il Trovatore goes way back to the Bjoerling, Milanov monaural LP. With the advent of the DVD, I had hoped for a performance that would do justice to this exceptional work but was very disappointed with the Cura, Villaroel version, where the staging was awful and the tenor was too. The Domingo, Kabaivanska disc was an exceptional performance conducted by von Karajan, but the picture and sound suffered simply because of the age of the original taping. But the opera gods have blessed me exceptionally well with this incredibly well done performance.Not only is this performance musically near perfect (with  the exception of using the usual cuts, although Leonora's last act cabaletta is performed) but the staging is wonderful, with singers who can act as well as sing. I think it was Caruso who noted that a good Trovatore requires four world class singers at the top of their game, and the pricipals here are exactly that.Trovatore, of course, is blamed for having a confusing, lame plot; after all, what other opera has been parodied by Gilbert & Sullivan AND the Marx Brothers? But as William Berger notes in his splendid book, "Verdi with a Vengeance", modern news routinely features far more gruesome events in real life than those contained in the plot. As for the singers ...In Sondra Radvanovsky we have the Verdi soprano that many have hoped for since the days of Leontyne Price. From top to bottom and all places in between, she has the perfect voice and superb vocal technique. And Boy!! can she act!! Just sample the convent scene, where Manrico, whom she believes to be dead reappears alive and well. THAT is what opera is all about!!Hvorostovsky is simply the best Count di Luna since Leonard Warren, IMHO. The voice is huge, but capable of surprising delicacy in the softer passages. His rendition if Il Balen is superb!Alvarez is similarly exceptional here. I have seen him in other operas where his acting is less than more. but David McVicar got a terrific performance from him, although he is a bit frenetic at times. Vocally, he is quite good, but I get the sense that there are parts where the role seems a bit heavy for his spinto voice and there he sounds forced.Dolora Zajick has sung a lot of Azucenas in her career, but there's no letup in the intensity of her performance. Vocally and dramatically, she's the real deal!Marco Armeliato is splendid in the pit. I have followed his career since the 2008 Baden Baden concert on DVD and remain impressed by him. While he moves this energetic work at tempo, there are times when he slows a bit to bring out both the emotion in the score and the rich interpretations of his singers.Disc quality is perfect; picture and sound are all that I have come to expect from DGG. Subtitles are in the usaul languages, plus one oriental one designated by (to me) an undeciferable sign. Extras are limited to the usual insipid cast interviews that the Met cannot seem to get past.I cannot imagine a better performed Il Trovatore than this one. While cheaper deals are available, you can buy and enjoy.No disappointments here!!

reviewText: David McVicar's opera stagings invite you to come in, sit down, relax, and enjoy.He shows you how beautiful even a Verismo opera can be with all it's raw emotions and passions of love and hate, and not to forget "vendetta". He allows the music, the set and costume designers, as well as the singers to be the stars without weaving in his own stories or disregarding the composer's as you so often see in today's Regietheater guided operas. This straight up production is a really wonderful introduction to "Il Trovatore" for those who are not familiar with the opera. You don't need to read anything about it beforehand in order to understand it. (I wish I had seen it before I saw Olivier Py's sensory overload, nightmarish, black and white mise en scene of "Il Trovatore" in Munich last year.) McVicar's mise en scene is in living color on a well lit rotating set and features a very capable cast of singers. My favorite was Dolora Zajick who sang Azucena to perfection with her warm, rich mezzo voice and incredible technique and control. Sondra Radvanovsky's soprano is also rich and full and she is a very likeable Leonora. Marcelo Alvarez sings Manrico with a lyrical tenor voice and really pulls out all the stops with his "all' armi!" His "Ah! si ben mio.." is romantic and beautiful. And last but not least is Dmitri Hvorostovsky as Count di Luna. His stage presence and acting is in a class by itself, his singing always a joy to the ears. This opera is hosted by the gorgeous Renee Fleming who also interviews the cast back stage.
summary: David McVicar's "Il Trovatore" at the Met

reviewText: IL TROVATORE, at this writing the eleventh most frequently performed work in the Metropolitan's annals, has had a checkered recent history at that theater. David McVicar's production, seen here in a revival two years following its 2009 debut, represented an uptick in TROVATORE's fortunes. It replaced a notorious production by Graham Vick, which had premiered in the late 1990s to much derision and was subsequently "gutted" by then-GM Joseph Volpe, to such a degree that Vick asked his name be removed from it. It did not augur well when McVicar was quoted as saying, "On a bad day I think IL TROVATORE is one of the stupidest operas ever written. Before I took it on, I thought that. But that's why I took it on." But the Scottish director went on to deliver a production that is, in the main, apposite and sturdy, likely capable of accommodating new casts in the coming years. He employs the Met stage's turntable to achieve fluidity and momentum from scene to scene, and his direction is specific, dynamic and physical. Occasionally the dynamism and physicality go too far, as if McVicar believes Verdi's music will not hold attention without the aid of a lot of extraneous "business." Azucena changing Manrico's bandages during their first scene together is a nice touch, but I could have done without two supernumerary gypsies' frenetic swordplay during the Anvil Chorus, and even more so the array of strumpets brought on for the Count's men to graphically hump during a chorus in Act III.It is easy to see why the soprano Sondra Radvanovsky has been a polarizing figure. She has a large voice that easily fills the Met and has some cut to it in ensembles, and in this respect, she is ideal for certain roles the Met has had a hard time satisfactorily casting in recent decades. Whether it is a large voice that is easy on the ears is something else. Her metallic tone, tending toward shrillness near the top, has never been one flattered by microphones. More troublesomely, there are imperfections of pitch, and at no dynamic level is her tremulous, fluttery sound steadily produced. The soaring phrases of Leonora's aristocratic music are not well served; this is a rather rough-sounding performance. Both Radvanovsky and her Manrico, Marcelo Álvarez, are poor actors -- she tries too hard, he not enough, relying on a lot of stock tenor mannerisms that add up to old-fashioned, better-heard-than-seen vapidity. His singing is more pleasing, although one has the impression of an essentially lyric instrument being pushed hard.To a lesser extent, the same can be said of the Count di Luna, Dmitri Hvorostovsky, who often must sacrifice some of the natural beauty of his tone to pump out sound for Verdi baritone roles, especially in this large venue. Some characteristic harsh intakes of breath (though the breath control per se is superb) will be more or less bothersome to taste. As ever, Hvorostovsky makes good use of his considerable charisma. Also commanding on stage is the Ferrando, Stefan Kocán. He cannot convincingly bear the history of the old soldier who saw and remembers it all -- he looks and is younger than the Count -- but his compact, Mozartean bass moves well to the specifications of Verdi's music in the important opening narration. The best singing of the afternoon comes from the 59-year-old Dolora Zajick, who was the Azucena on the 1988 Met DVD as well. The power of her voice is remarkably well preserved, and it is a musically scrupulous performance, but -- I am not sure whether to blame Zajick or McVicar -- there isn't much dementia or madness in this gypsy. The production seems to emphasize the character's shrewd and calculating side, rather than the chaos and disorder of her wandering mind; but even with that allowance made, it is a bland impersonation. Maria Zifchak, who has appeared frequently in the Met's HD broadcasts and DVDs (most memorably as Suzuki in MADAMA BUTTERFLY), is an excellent Ines.Marco Armiliato conducts a mild, understated TROVATORE, unobjectionable but not the last word in either elegance or  energy. The Met Orchestra operates at a predictably high level, with special commendation for the brass. The chorus is in very fine form; they, Hvorostovsky, Kocán, and Zajick combine to make Act III Scene 1 the opera's high point. Edition-wise, some bad old habits still have not died hard -- for example, Álvarez follows tradition by joining Radvanovsky halfway through her arching final phrase ("Sei tu dal ciel disceso" et cetera) at the end of the Convent Scene, and of course the tenor is allowed to go vocally MIA for his lines with Ruiz and the Armed Men at the conclusion of "Di quella pira" (transposed down) so as to conserve for the unwritten high note.For what it is worth, this is a better showing than the Met's earlier entry in the catalog (Marton, Zajick, Pavarotti, Milnes; Levine), and there is something to be said for its advantages of modernity -- excellent camerawork, picture and sound, and relative textual fullness (the duettino for tenor and soprano with organ accompaniment; one verse of "Tu vedrai che amore"). But I would give none of the principals an edge over Kabaivanska, Cossotto, Domingo, Cappuccilli, and Van Dam on the 1978 Karajan/Vienna DVD with the traditional cuts. In the case of the soprano and tenor, it isn't even close. A commercial DVD of La Scala's 2000 TROVATORE television broadcast, with Muti conducting Frittoli, Urmana, Licitra, and Nucci in a note-complete reading of the David Lawton/University of Chicago critical edition, would be most welcome.
